zone.line: ?Regarding phenomema
Such things as theese I assent that it belongs to
a soothsayer both to observe & to judge re
such
respecting these appearances as these. - Ion And you
assert the truth o Socrates. Soc. And you also
my dear Ion - For we have both in our turn recited
from the Odyssey & the Iliad whatever re passages
relating to vaticination to medicine & the piscatorial
-torial art; and as you are more skilled in Homer
do you now tell make mention of
than I can be, you have not omitted whatever
for a rhapsodist is
relates to the rhapsodist & his art; competent as
you are above all other men, to consider and pronounce
his art
on whatever has relation to rhapsody. Soc.
Or with respect to any every thing else mentiond
by Homer.- Ion Do not be so forgetful as to
say every thing. A good memory is particularly
necessary for a rhapsodist. Ion. And what
do I forget? Soc Do you not remember that
you admitted the art of reciting verses was
different
distinct from that of driving chariots? Ion. I remember
And did you not admit that being different
the subjects of its knowledge were must also
be distinct. Ion. Certainly. Soc. You will not
assert that the art of rhapsody is that of
universal knowledge; a rhapsodist may be ignorant
